title: Not for your infants!
content: This product was given by my pharmacy in place of the thickening agent that was prescribed for my aspirating 5 month old daughter.  She immediately started having severely runny BMs after being a regular clay-once-a-dayer.  Turns out this is made of modified food starch and maltodextrin.  It even notes on the container that 1 serving of 2 Tablespoons = 1/2 fruit serving.  As a thickener for an infant, it's 2Tbsp per 4-5oz bottle - 6 times a day - or 3 fruit servings....!  No wonder she had watery poos - the kind where we change her a minimum of 3x day.  It was ridiculous and completely unsuitable for an infant. Like giving way too much apple juice for constipation.  WAY too much. Also, when used for aspirating, it doesn't thicken evenly, so it really didn't do the job for aspirating as well as it gets thicker with time so it was awful trying to get the bottles to work with daycare.  I hated all 14 days we used this product and refuse to use it again. Total nightmare. I think this may be a good product for adults but most certainly not aspirating infants.

It does say on the container "For best results, consume within 30 minutes of mixing" which I wish I knew before buying this huge container, but when someone has Dysphagia with liquids they tend to take smaller sips and don't always finish it within 30 minutes!!!! My son goes to an adult day program and I have to mix his drinks before hand (as they cannot because of liability) and I got a note saying that it was too thin and he was CHOKING! Not a good thing. title: It does help!
content: My dog has a condition called laryngeal paralysis. This is where the flaps to the windpipe don't work anymore and she could not breath. This made it hard for her to drink with out having some of the water go down the wrong pipe and she coughed and choked after every drinking. Eating was fine, just the drinking. I saw this product and im glad I did! You add a little powder to the liquid, stir it good, then let it sit for 30 seconds and it slowly thickens. You have to play around with the amount until you get the right thickness. For 4 fluid oz I use 2 table spoons but I am still playing with the amount. This has helped my dog very much. She can drink now with out it going down the wrong pipe. I tasted it just to see what I was dealing with and you don't taste a difference. Just the texture is different. title: Is helping Dad
content: My dad had to have a total laryngectomy about 2 years ago due to laryngeal cancer. Living in the rural south, he and my mom have to drive about 3.5 hours (one way) when it is time for that prosthetic voice apparatus to  be changed out. 7 total hours of driving and heavy, traffic in a tourist city around a busy research hospital is tough. I did that drive many times for them when he was still undergoing treatments and having surgeries. He has found that the closer he gets to needing the prosthetic changed, the more he coughs when he drinks water or other thin liquids. He describes it as "leaking". Also, there are time when he feels that the prosthetic shifts and presses against the back of the throat causing choking. But since the visits to have the prosthetic reinstalled or adjusted are costly and not a hop, skip and jump away, he endures the discomfort. It feels to him like the prosthetic has shifted and is allowing liquid to leak into his lungs -- and as a result, convulsive coughing ensues. So I ordered this and it helps. He is still about a week and a half away from his next appointment to be refitted and the coughing is still really bad but with the thickener, its bearable. Before, he was so miserable and bitter that he was lashing out and being exceptionally negative. (He may have also been getting dehydrated which can cause mood disturbances.) He was absolutely killing my mom. That constant crossness and lashing out can really do a number on the spouse who has had to assume the role of "caretaker". I mean, my Dad is not disabled, but the ordeal of cancer has changed him and he depends on her more and sometimes seems to resent her "wholeness". Since he got this product (only 5 days ago), he and my mom (who are both retired) have taken two nice day trips to shop and eat in cities about an hour away all in the same week. All before, he had been sitting in the house day after day saying one negative thing after the other, vegging out in front of the tv and feeding off of negative news programs. Now he's out on a "date" with my mom and he is even talking about getting a nice room and spending the night with my mom in Charleston when they drive down for his refitting. And my dad is usually very money conscious (i.e., cheap!) so for him, this is big. No, this product may not alleviate all swallowing problems but for a person who has been suffering from a diminished quality of life due to swallowing issues, this product can be a game changer. For my dad, it gives him some power back - a tool to add to his arsenal of things he can do to help manage his condition. I think feeling helpless is where all that excessive negativity was coming from. Wish I had known about this sooner.

title: Thick it with swallow disorder
content: I have used Thick it for several years now. Husband has upper dysphagia (a swallow disorder) Upper Dysphagia has no cure, but you can help by using this. It will help lessen events of Aspiration Pneumonia. Dysphagia can be caused by things such as stroke, Cancer of the throat and even repeat pneumonia episodes mainly in the elderly. This product can also be used with infants and small children,  however,  NEVER give a baby or small child any new changes to his diet without a Dr's order. Thick it is tasteless. Remember that it takes an adjustment period to any patient going to a  regular liquid to a thicker consistency, so keep practicing in how much you use. A little hint: Start out a bit thicker than needed. The patient will say they aren't drinking that! Then make another small amount with a little less thickness. Make sure a cold drink is really COLD! I add ice to the drink BEFORE the thick it,  stir the ice till it's mostly melted,  then scoop out the remaining ice cube ( you DON'T want them to choke!) NOW add thick it! What a person with swallowing issues desires is a refreshing cold going down the throat. I really give it a fast hard stir till powder is well dissolved. You may add a touch of lemon to water,  a little real (or artificial if diabetic) sugar to make it a little more flavorful. My husband loves ice tea. I use the above method of making it. He has to have very close to pudding thick and uses a spoon to "eat" it. Swallow issues state using NO straws or sports bottles. Be sure the patient can be positioned @ 30 degree angle ( NO LAYING FLAT!!) The patient can aspirate anything if they are laying down. Just practice using patient's face drinks till you get good results in thickness needed.  Thicken applesauce, soup broth, ect. I think the 2 most difficult things to thicken are milk and coffee. A person with dysphagia will have a limited diet change. Cold cereal, things like Cole slaw,  salad ( basic foods that can choke must be avoided! Have your Dr order speech therapy. Medicare will pay for 100% for IN HOME care. Use that insurance FIRST ! Many visits to the home are allowed before they stop paying! Easier on the patient to learn swallow excercises in comfort of home.  Home health is there to also help show you tips, train you and make you confident in what you're doing. By time home health care is done,  patient will understand why the excercises, ect are so important & you (Caregiver) will be able to handle this health issue like a pro. Patience & common sense are the key!

Most liquids, such as coffee and milk that I know I will use a consistent amount of in the next day or two, I mix up in bottles of 46-64 ozs the night before and keep in the fridge and it saves on the frustration of waiting and watching each serving to thicken. It works well in hot or cold. Seems to work exceptionally well to thicken soup bases. I will ladle a half amount of broth into soup cup or bowl and add thickener, it thickens quite fast, then I’ll add the noodles, veggies, and meat of what ever soup I’m thickening and it’s the perfect consistency every time. title: Food/liquid thickener for people with swallow difficulty
content: This product thickens food and liquid so that people who have problem swallowing (i.e. aspiration pneumonia) can safely digest their meals. My elderly father suffered from this condition and end up in the hospital.  His speech therapist recommended this product.  Every meal my father had was mixed with this powder into honey consistency, including his drinking water. I ordered two of these large 36oz containers in anticipation of my father coming home.  Each container has clear instruction on the side of the box and a measuring spoon inside.  Unfortunately my father passed away before he could come home.  I was able to return my order without any problems.  My seller was Homeline Medical Inc.  I appreciate their quick customer service and hassle-free return.  I highly recommend this seller for their great price, fast delivery, and, of course, their great customer service! Note - signs of aspiration pneumonia are coughing and wheezing, followed by fever.  People who suffer from this condition have food/liquid going into their lungs instead of the esophagus.  This can lead to bacterial infection in the lungs (as was the case for my father). You need to get medical attention ASAP because the patient requires antibiotic and oxygen in their system.

title: I use in salad dressings, sauces, frosting...
content: I was forced to consume this stuff in the hospital after a tracheotomy, and I thought I'd never want to see it again! However, I eventually realized something like this could come in very handy in the kitchen. My previous go-to no-cook thickener was xanthan gum, but my son HATES when I use it in anything! This *just* thickens things, without making them stretchy or slimy or lumpy. When I pack lunches, I add it to tuna & chicken salad to thicken up the lemon juice or vinegar and help keep the bread from getting soggy; I've used it to thicken up runny store-bought jam, yogurt, and cottage cheese. I use it to replace some of the mayo in creamy salad dressings and sugar in cake frosting, thereby reducing the calories. It helps stabilize whipped cream.It is the same starch used in instant pudding mixes, so you can use it to create your own recipes (with fewer artificial flavors/colors, if desired), or turn any beverage like juice, soda, iced coffee, or flavored milk (chocolate, strawberry, Ovaltine, etc) into a pudding. Mixes & dissolves so well in hot or cold liquid! I find it more convenient than regular cornstarch, which has to be dissolved in cold liquid;  if you've already added all the ingredients to your recipe but it's looking watery, you can just stir in some Thick-It without adding more liquid as you'd have to with cornstarch. In my opinion, some thickeners like cornstarch or glucomannan dull the flavor of my food, while Thick-It either doesn't have that effect or it must be much more subtle, because I don't notice a change in flavor. I love this stuff! It is pure carbs so, being diabetic, I do have to use it sparingly, but a teaspoon or a tablespoon is usually quite enough for a recipe that makes several servings.

content: I was forced to consume this stuff in the hospital after a tracheotomy, and I thought I'd never want to see it again!
